title: The Feast of Axos
author: Mike Maddox
filename: 144 - The Feast of Axos - Mike Maddox_djvu.txt

elements.text: PART ONE
PRE-CREDITS: REPRISE FROM THE GATHERING SWARM
Brewster! I might have known! Once a cutpurse, always a cutpurse!
What are you doing here? Thomas?
FX: THE SAFETY CATCH OF A REVOLVER.
Guess.
Oh, please. Put the gun down, Brewster.
You don’t get it, do you? This is a hi-jack.
A hi-jack?
You’re gonna take me back to my own time. Now!
Excuse me, but I do not take orders from any common thief!
No more talk, Doctor. Drive!
MUSIC: OPENING THEME
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 3
SCENE 1: INT. FLIGHT DECK OF SPACESHIP WINDERMERE
FX: FAINT HUM OF ENGINES. LOW, DISCREET BEEPS FROM INSTRUMENTS.
EASYJET FLIGHT DECK THAN ENTERPRISE.
(RADIO) Mission control to Spaceship Windermere, you are go for burn. Repeat, go for burn.
Roger that, Devesham. Four. Three. Two. One. And burn.
FX: ROCKET MOTOR BURNING OUTSIDE CABIN.
We are at burn. Telemetry check. Go with throttles up.
(RADIO) Throttles up, Windermere. Looking good, David.
Boosters at max and holding. (TO JOANNE) You alright back there, Miss Slade?
I can’t believe it. We’re in space! We’re actually in space!
Nice view, isn’t it? Look. Tropical storm over the Gulf. See it? And over there, the great Oklahoma desert. I can remember when this was all fields.
It’s incredible. How do you ever get used to this?
You don’t.
Good job too, or we’d be out of business.
Ohh, space tourism’s here to stay, you’re set up for life. —
FX: COMMS BUZZ.
(RADIO) We don’t like the “T” word, Miss Slade. It’s affordable
low-orbit travel. Not tourism.
Is that — [Campbell1?]
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 4
(RADIO) Devesham calling. Campbell here.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 5
SCENE 2: INT. MISSION CONTROL
FX: HOUSTON, BASICALLY — BUSY BUZZ OF TECHNICIANS HUNCHED OVER
MONITORS.
(DISTORTED, VIA BIG SCREEN) Reading you loud and clear, Mr Irons, sir.
(D) Sorry, Mr Irons, I didn’t mean —

Thirty years ago, Miss Slade, when we first began this little venture, they said all we were doing was giving joy rides for the mega-rich — for Russian oligarchs, Texan billionaires, rock stars with more money than sense. Well, we proved them wrong. It’s still not cheap, I know, but now we offer space flight for the price of a luxury cruise.
(D) I realise that, of course, sir —
But as of today, Miss Slade — Joanne — as of today, everything changes. Today marks not just the first flight of the Windermere, but the first day of Britain’s future in a post- carbon world!
(OFF) Sorry, Mr Irons, sir, but we really should —

We’ve got time. Here on Earth, people are scared. The oil’s running dry. They fear for their jobs. They fear for the future. Today, we can change all that. Clean, green, unlimited energy for all. You know what this means to me. You know what you mean to me.
(D) Thank you, sir. It means a lot to us, too, knowing you’re down there, watching our every step.
It’s the least I can do, Joanne. And — Squadron Leader Swanson? Mister Brock?
DAVID/CRAIG: (D) Hello, sir./Yes, sir.
Bring me my ship back in one piece!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 6
SCENE 3: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
FX: FADE IN. B/G HUM. CLICK OF GUN BEING COCKED.
Thomas, there’s no need for this —
I said drive. Doctor?
Very well. Your own time, did you say? (FX: DOCTOR OPERATING
CONTROLS.) Let’s see... how about eighteen-seventy? Near enough?
Yeah, that’ll do.
Simply a matter of setting the co-ordinates...
FX: BUTTONS PRESSED — ACTIVATING A SENSORY DISTORTION
AS IN ‘GATHERING SWARM’ SCENE 43.
(RENDERED IMMOBILE) W-what have you done to me-?
Activated the TARDIS’s sensory disorientation force-field, that’s all.
But — I can’t move!
That’s the idea. Evelyn — take the gun off Mr Brewster, please.
FX: EVELYN DOES SO.
What do you want me to do with it?
Pass it to me. Carefully. Now, Thomas, are you willing to behave?
Just let us out of this, will you?!?
I’1ll take that as a yes.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page
FX: FORCEFIELD DE-ACTIVATED.
(GETS BREATH) Like being stuck in a vice.
There was no need to point a gun at me, you know. You could simply have asked nicely.
And you’d have taken us where I wanted to go?
I would have considered it. But I’m rather disinclined to co- operate with anyone who threatens to shoot me!
I wasn’t gonna shoot you, not really.
I’m sorry, but then what was the gun for? Dramatic effect?
Check the magazine, Doctor.
FX: REVOLVER OPENED UP.
Empty. It wasn’t loaded.
You were bluffing?
So it seems.
I don’t shoot people. I’m not a wrong ‘un.
Excuse me, young man, but the last time we met you left me in an underground chamber to be possessed by an alien planet!
Hey, you’re still alive, ain’t you?
No thanks to you!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 8
I think the best thing to do would be to place Brewster here in the custody of the police. I suggest we drop in on Detective Inspector Menzies, and let justice take its course!
FX: CO-ORDINATES BEING SET.
Doctor, I told you, there ain’t nothing for me in the twenty- first century —
And there’s nothing for you in the TARDIS, either. You made your bed, Thomas Brewster, you lie in it. And that is my final word on the matter!
FX: TARDIS VWORPING AWAY.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 9
SCENE 4: INT. FLIGHT DECK OF SPACESHIP WINDERMERE
FX: AS BEFORE.
(RADIO) Green go on de-orbit manoeuvre.
Course adjustment. Craig, pitch to nine point three.
Nine point three, check.
Thrust vector burn in three. Two. One. —
FX: SHORT BURN OF ROCKET.
Course adjustment confirmed.
So, Craig — not missing the RAF?
Oh, I had a great time. Loved the life, loved the excitement, saw a bit of action in the Malayan War. But I wanted to go into Space. That was always the dream, ever since I was a kid.
When he applied, Campbell nearly bit his hand off.
Yaw adjust. Gimbals locked.
(RADIO) Check.
FX: SENSOR TRIPPED.
Time field threshold detected.
This is it. Remember, we’re likely to experience any number of strange effects once we cross the field threshold.
You mean — it’s all going to get weird from here on in?
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 10
Comms break imminent. Craig, Jo, David: before you pass the field threshold, all of us here at Devesham, we just want to say — good luck, and [God speed. —]
FX: DISSOLVES INTO STATIC.
OK. We’re on our own, kids. —
FX: PINGING LIKE RADAR.
Target in range.
MUSIC: SUGGESTS THE VAST BULK OF AXOS HOVING INTO VIEW.
And there she is.
It’s huge. And so, so —
Alien?
Orange.
FX: FEROCIOUS BURST OF FEEDBACK.
Whoa!
FX: FEEDBACK BURST RESOLVES ITSELF INTO:

(FLAT MONOTONE ON RADIO) [.. Earth, ] Axos calling Earth. Fuel system exhausted. Request immediate assistance. Immediate assistance. — [Axos calling Earth, Axos calling Earth. Fuel system exhausted. Request immediate assistance. Immediate assistance. —] (CONTINUES THROUGH: )
It’s talking to us!
Jo? What’s going on?
It’s the time distortion, I warned you. We’re picking up transmissions going backwards and forwards in time.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 11
So which was that? Backwards or forwards?
Backwards.
You hope.
We’re hearing the original broadcast. The one Axos made when it first contacted Earth, back in the twentieth century.
You’re sure?
I’ve studied to that recording hundreds of times. (FX: VOICE OF
FADES OUT.) Trust me, it’s just a blast from the past. Axos is dormant.
FX: FADE UP, FROM SCENE XX:
(RADIO DISTORT) This is the spaceship Windermere. —
Hang on. Is that you?
(RADIO DISTORT) Our mission is a success. Axos is safe. Repeat, Axos is [made safe. —] (FX: FADES OUT QUICKLY.)
Forwards. That was forwards.
That was you — in the future?
Axos is stuck in a figure of eight, looping through four dimensions. We’re going right inside that loop, so...
I trust you, Jo. It’s going to be fine. Weird, but fine.
I think we should go for an approach run.
FX: ROCKET QUICK BURN.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 12
(RADIO DISTORT) [This] .. is the spaceship Windermere. Our mission is a [success. ]
Oh, great, you again.
It means it’s going to work. We send a message back to ourselves, to let us know it all works out fine.
(RADIO DISTORT) [.. the] spaceship Windermere. Our mission is a success.
Yeah, we got that part, love. Change the record.
(RADIO DISTORT) Our mission —
[.. calling] Earth, Axos calling Earth. Fuel system [exhausted—]
(RADIO DISTORT) .. is a success.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 13
SCENE 5: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
FX: TARDIS IN FLIGHT.
Not long now.
You needn’t look so pleased about it.
I don’t understand, Doctor. If Brewster here is from the Victorian age — what was he doing in 2011?
That was the Doctor’s doing. When I was his companion before, that’s where he dropped me off.
And I’m sorry it didn’t work out, but the fact remains, Thomas — it’s time you faced the music!
I’m not sure I see the harm, in taking him back where he came from.
Yeah, me neither.
The harm is Thomas Brewster himself! That boy, Evelyn — that boy, wherever and whenever I take him, he’s a menace!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 14
SCENE 6: INT. FLIGHT DECK OF SPACESHIP WINDERMERE
FX: CUT UP SECTIONS OF PAST AND FUTURE MESSAGES, PHASING IN AND
(RADIO DISTORT) Axos calling Earth, Axos calling Earth. Fuel system exhausted. Request immediate assistance. Immediate assistance.
(RADIO DISTORT) This is the spaceship Windermere. Our mission is a success. Axos is safe. Repeat, Axos is made safe.
(OVER) Okay, that’s enough of that. I can’t hear myself think.
FX: RADIO CUT OFF.
Craig. They could have told us something important.
If it’s not the winning numbers for next week’s global lottery, I don’t need to know. (BEAT) We’re approaching the threshold. Jo, you ready with that magic box of yours?
Yeah, you just concentrate on steering, okay?
FX: JO POWERING UP DISPLACEMENT DEVICE — BLIPS ON KEYPAD.
What is that thing, exactly?

Recovered alien tech, as if you couldn’t tell by looking at it. There was stuff falling out of the sky like confetti in the last century. This was found in a field in Kent. So far as we can figure it out, given it didn’t come with a manual, it’s like a shield, displacing the flow of time about an area of space.
Not much of a time machine, then.
No, but we figure it’1ll protect us from any physical damage as we cross the threshold, and enter the time loop itself.
Physical damage-?
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 15
You know — us suddenly ageing to death, that sort of thing.
Yeah, but that’s not likely, is it-?
Not to death, no. But the loop was first placed nearly fifty years ago, so —
What, we might turn eighty in an instant?
Got to admit — I topped up my pension, just to be sure.
Hold on to that happy thought, here comes the threshold in five. Four. Three. Two. [One. ]
Activating — now.
FX: HORRIBLE SQUEALING SOUND, LIKE DONALD SUTHERLAND IN
MIXED WITH AN ANIMAL IN PAIN. HORRIBLE.
Turn it off! Turn it off!
I can’t!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 16
SCENE 7: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
FX: TARDIS IN FLIGHT.
Brewster, here? A menace? How?

Don’t let the ‘poor me’ face fool you, Evelyn. He’s already happily conversant with twenty-first century history and technology. If I take him back to the nineteenth century, trust me — he’ll use every scrap of foreknowledge he’s gleaned in his own self-interest!
You don’t know that.
Aw, leave it, missus. He’s just sore about the damage to his Holy Joe reputation, what with me going round calling meself ‘The Doctor’.
Yes, and that’s the second time you’ve pulled that particular
stunt, which rather proves my point — a leopard doesn’t change its [spots!]
FX: THE AWFUL SQUEALING NOISE FROM THE WINDERMERE CRASHES IN.
What the Devil is that?
Doctor?
(FX: BUTTONS, LEVERS.) I don’t know!
Make it stop!
FX: TARDIS MAKES UNHAPPY NOISES, IN DISTRESS.
Hey, is it supposed to make that noise?
No, it’s not! —
FX: NOISE FADES AWAY.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB)
There, that’s better.
That sound — it was like a fox in a snare, screaming.
It was horrible.
(FX: SCANNING NOISES.) It was a cry for help. Someone or something is in pain.
Where’s it coming from?
The Time Vortex. Someone is playing around with time technology.
Another Time Lord?
No.. I don’t think so. Whoever it is, they don’t have the faintest idea what it is they’re doing!
Page 17
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page
SCENE 8: INT. FLIGHT DECK OF SPACESHIP WINDERMERE
FX: FADE UP. THE SCREAMING CUTS OFF SUDDENLY. B/G AS BEFORE.
It’s stopped.
What was that? Jo? Jo!
I don’t know, I don’t know what it was -
I thought you were the expert on alien stuff.
It must... it must have been something to do with crossing the threshold. Some kind of temporal feedback.
Anything on the instruments?
Nothing. Everything’s reading normal.
And we've not aged fifty years, so that’s a bonus.
Not on the outside, maybe. My guts, on the other hand —
Come on, people, we all need to focus. David — distance to target?
Two point six kilometres.
Check retros. Coming about.
FX: ROCKET QUICK BURN.
There it is again. Axos. You are sure it’s dead?
We wouldn’t be here if it was dead. It’s hibernating, we think.
But still, very much alive...
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 19
SCENE 9: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
FX: TARDIS TICKING OVER.
So this time interference is causing someone or something to cry out in pain?
Yes. Let’s see exactly what. Scanner, please, Evelyn. —
It’s alright, I can do that.
FX: SCANNER OPENING.
Earth. Low orbit. Oh, now that looks familiar!
What on Earth is it? Looks like a pitcher plant, floating in space.
Honestly, if you want something doing, don’t leave it to your former selves to sort out. I wonder what’s wrong?
Looks harmless enough.
Harmless? Harmless?!? That — is a parasitic organism, a vampire from space, drifting from planet to planet to suck their energy dry. It’s called Axos.
Well, it doesn’t seem to be doing anything much right now.
What? No, do pay attention, Evelyn. It tried to feed on the Earth years ago, but I trapped it in a time loop. Trouble was, my TARDIS was, er, compromised, and half my memory was missing.
So you bodged the job?
Well, it was all the Time Lords’ fault. They’d stranded me on Earth.
Why?
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox
Why?!?
Yes, Doctor. Why?
Oh, stupid reasons.
Such as-?
Oh, mostly to do with stealing the TARDIS.
What — you stole the TARDIS?
Technically.
And he dares to have a pop at me?!?
FX: DOCTOR SETTING CO-ORDINATES.
None of this is relevant right now. Right now, suspect that someone or something is interfering with Axos — and it’s my business to put a stop to them!
FX: VWORPING AWAY.
Page 20
I strongly
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 21
SCENE 10: INT. FLIGHT DECK OF SPACESHIP WINDERMERE
FX: ANOTHER BURST OF ENGINES.
Axos straight ahead, one kilometre and closing.
See anything, Jo?
No. No sign of a hatch. So — David —
— we stick to the A plan. Fly into its mouth.
Dock with its mouth.
There’s a difference-?
FX: BEEPS.
Just take us in nice and easy. Fingers crossed we can get it to open up.
Jo, Craig — you know what comes next. Get down to the cargo bay.
E.V.A. time. (SARCASTIC) Great.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 22
SCENE 11: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
FX: TARDIS LANDS AND ROTOR STOPS. SCANNER OPENS. AXOS INTERIOR
OVER SCANNER.
We’re inside this ‘Axos’, then?
In one of the minor arteries, by the look of it.
What’s that flickering? — There!
Nerve endings, I expect. (FX: CONSOLE BLEEPS.) Ah.
‘Ah’?
Pressure — variable; atmosphere — very variable; oxygen — thin.
Which means, what-?
Ohh no. You are not getting me in a spacesuit!
It’s either that, I’m afraid, or sit this one out in the TARDIS. There’s a good selection in the wardrobe room...
What, of Barbarella’s cast-offs? (BEAT; THEN EXITS) Alright, alright — I’1l find something...
FX: INTERIOR DOOR.
You’d better go and get suited up too, Thomas.
It’s alright, I don’t mind waiting in here.
Nice try, but I think not. No, I want you right where I can see you.
And afterwards, Doctor? You going to take me home?
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 23
Give me one good reason why I should.
Because it’s where I belong. I’d stay out of trouble.
Somehow I doubt that. Selling off my TARDIS, bit by bit? Kidnapping innocent people? Running a criminal gang? Pretending to be me?!?
Trying to be like you, Doctor. (BEAT) I wouldn’t do anything — you know, to change the future and that. I’ve seen enough to know better. You do know that, don’t you?
BEAT
Perhaps. Prove to me I can trust you, and... and, well, I might be persuaded to reconsider.
Deal?
Deal. Go on, if you’re going. Third door on the right. Mine’s the one with the fishbowl helmet.
Got you. (BEAT) Thanks, Doctor. (EXITS)
(CALLING AFTER) And while you’re about it, you’d better tell Evelyn — make sure you get suits for oxygen-breathers!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page
SCENE 12: INT. CARGO HOLD OF SPACESHIP WINDERMERE
FX: JOANNE AND CRAIG PUTTING ON SPACESUITS.
(STRUGGLING) Ohh, I hate these suits —
Hold still while I check your seals.
It’s not easy when you’re floating upside down.
Actually — I’m upside down, you’re the right way up.
(RADIO) Thank you, Craig. Don’t want the lady losing her breakfast in a confined space, do we?
Right. Harness on. Do people do that often? Get sick I mean?
(RADIO) Nine times out of ten, but we don’t mention it in the
brochure.
Right, visors down. —
FX: 2 X CLICKS.
(RADIO) All good?
JOANNE/CRAIG: (FX: THROUGH SUIT MICS) Check./Check.
(RADIO) OK. Opening cargo bay doors. Hold tight.
FX: ELECTRONIC HUM AND OMINOUS CLANGS AS HATCH BEGINS TO OPEN
(FX: SUIT MIC) This is the bit I’ve been having the nightmare about...
Ss
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 25
SCENE 13: INT. TARDIS WARDROBE ROOM
FX: RUMMAGING THROUGH RACKS OF CLOTHES.
Honestly, this wardrobe is utterly unfathomable. I’m not sure if it’s supposed to be sorted by planet, date, colour or chest size.
(FX: PULLING SUIT OFF PEG) How’s this-?
It’s got gills, Thomas.
Ah. Right. (FX: REPLACING SUIT) I’m sorry about the — you know, what happened.
The attempted hijack, or abducting me to another planet?
Both.
Yes. We got off on the wrong foot, rather.
Several wrong feet. (FX: ANOTHER SUIT OFF RACK.) Here. Try this one for size. Don’t know about the colour, but at least it’s only got two arms.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 26
SCENE 14: INT. CARGO HOLD OF SPACESHIP WINDERMERE
FX: CLANG.
(RADIO) Cargo hatch now fully open.
(SUIT MIC) Roger. Hey, who’d have guessed, it’s a starry night out there. Jo? You OK?
(SUIT MIC) Yes. My pen’s just gone into orbit.
(SUIT MIC) You trained for this in a water tank. Space is different.
(SUIT MIC) You can say that again. It’s so clear, it’s almost as if you could reach out and touch the stars...
(SUIT MIC) Extending umbilical now. Jo, keep looking at me! It’s my first E.V.A. too, don’t forget, so whatever you’re
feeling, I’m feeling too. Just breath steady and don’t look down.
(SUIT MIC) Which way is down?
(SUIT MIC) I don’t know, but whichever way it is, don’t look there. OK. Here... we... go!
THEY LAUNCH THEMSELVES INTO SPACE.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 27
SCENE 15: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
So. How do I look? It was the best I could find in size Elephant.
Don’t be silly. It’s very...
. very?
. very you.
Says Flash Gordon, in his go-faster stripes.
Who’s Flash Gordon?
After your time, Buck Rogers.
What?
Right, then — helmets visors down —
FX: 3 x CLICKS, CLUNKS. SUIT MICS FROM HERE.
(SUIT MIC) .. and sealed. Ready?
(SUIT MIC) Yes, Flash.
(SUIT MIC) Follow me.
FX: DOORS OPENING. THEY WALK OUT INTO:
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 28
SCENE 16: AXOS — PASSAGEWAY
FX: GLOOPY ALIEN NOISES. THE TARDIS CREW SPEAK OVER RADIO
VERY 2001, INTERRUPTED BY NASA “BLEEP” EVERY TIME THEY
TALKING. AXOS IS VAST AND CAVERNOUS — THEY’RE LIKE
INSIDE THE WHALE.
(SUIT MIC) It’s alright, just tread carefully.
(SUIT MIC) Yeah, the ground ain’t too firm. Reminds me of me mudlarkin’ days.
(SUIT MIC) Reminds me of a bouncy castle.
(SUIT MIC) Come on — we should be able to trace the artery back to the heart of the ship. Quite literally.
FX: DOCTOR HEADS OFF, BREWSTER AND EVELYN FOLLOWING SLOWLY.
(SUIT MIC) Hey, Doctor, slow down!
(SUIT MIC) What is it about wandering around inside veins and arteries! Don’t do it for years, and suddenly you’re doing it two days in a row!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 29
SCENE 17: EXT. SPACE (BESIDE AXOS)
(SUIT MIC) Right. I’m outside the Windermere. I can just touch the exterior surface of Axos. It’s soft, almost frictionless. I can’t get a purchase.
(SUIT MIC) Give us a second. I’m reaching up to insert the
relay line. Firing harpoon now.
FX: WHOOSH OF HARPOON. ORGANIC SPLAT AS IT IMPACTS ON AXOS.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 30
SCENE 18: INT. AXOS — PASSAGEWAY
FX: GENTLE RUMBLE.
(SUIT MIC) What was that? Like an earthquake.
(SUIT MIC) I don’t know. Thomas, shine your light against the membranes here.
(SUIT MIC) It’s breathing. Is it breathing?
(SUIT MIC) If it helps to think of it like that, then yes. Axos is a composite creature. I think it’s dreaming.
FX: RUSTLE OF TENDRILS.
(SUIT MIC) (SMALL SCREAM.) Ah! Something just — touched me!
(SUIT MIC) Try to mind out of the tendrils. They’re sensors, like cilia.
(SUIT MIC) Silly what?
(SUIT MIC) Nose hairs? We’re up a nostril-?!?
(SUIT MIC) Evelyn, are you sure you don’t want to go back to the TARDIS?
(SUIT MIC) No! No, I think I’1l stay with you, if that’s alright.
(SUIT MIC) I wouldn’t mind going back...
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 31
SCENE 19: EXT. SPACE (BESIDE AXOS)
(SUIT MIC) Ugh. It’s bleeding.
(SUIT MIC) It’s organic, what did you expect? OK. Help me take the line back to the Windermere. Gently, yeah? We don’t want to tear the skin membrane.
(SUIT MIC) I know, I know. (TO SHIP) David? We’re making our way back to the cargo bay. We’1ll let you know when we can extend the docking tunnel.
(RADIO) Roger. No hurry. You be safe out there.
(SUIT MIC) Jo? You OK?
(SUIT MIC) I was just thinking — she’s beautiful, isn’t she? Axos, I mean. Like a sea anemone, drifting on the solar wind... I know, I know, we don’t have time for [this—]
CRAIG/ JOANNE: (SUIT MIC) (JERKED ABOUT ON END OF LINE) Whoa!/Oh!!!
(RADIO) Craig? Jo? You alright out there?
(SUIT MIC) We’re fine. It — moved. Axos. Like a pulse, running right through the relay line.
(SUIT MIC) Axos is taking in energy.
(RADIO) Energy? From where?
(SUIT MIC) From us, perhaps. It seems to have settled down now. Probably just an unconscious response...
(SUIT MIC) Love that ‘probably’.
(SUIT MIC) Come on, Craig, time to unpack the docking tunnel.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 32
SCENE 20: INT. AXOS — MAIN CHAMBER
FX: DOCTOR, EVELYN, BREWSTER ARRIVING IN CAVERNOUS ROOM. SPONGY
FLOORS, SO CAST MAKING EFFORT TO INDICATE WALKING RATHER THAN FOOTSTEPS.
(SUIT MIC) .. and here we are. The central chamber. The heart of Axos.
(SUIT MIC) It’s enormous. Like a cathedral made of jelly.
(SUIT MIC) I thought we were in a spaceship.
(SUIT MIC) We are. The spaceship is Axos. A vast organism with a Single mind, but with the ability to extrude smaller independent units, so it can relate to other species.
(SUIT MIC) Friendly, is it?
(SUIT MIC) No. It relates to them, and then it absorbs them. (FX: BLEEP FROM SUIT.) Aha! Pressure — one atmosphere; oxygen — well, that’1ll do.
FX: CLICK, RAISES HELMET VISOR. SUDDEN WHOOSH OF AIR.
(NORMAL — NO MIC) There, that’s better.
(SUIT MIC) We can take raise our visors?
(SUIT MIC) You sure?
Oh yes. We might as well save our oxygen for when we need it.
FX: 2 X CLICKS AS EVELYN & BREWSTER RAISE VISORS.
Oh. Smells like wet dogs. And feet. How odd. It’s like the rugby changing room after the boys beat Loughborough.
What were you doing in the rugby changing room?

EVELYN: (RADIO) Hello.
DOCTOR: (RADIO) And as you can probably see, there are two British astronauts stuck here with us. Don’t suppose there’s any chance of a lift, [-— is there?]
DOCTOR: LeFEVRE:
DOCTOR: Pardon, but I am losing your signal. Please repeat, over? Shuttle Jules Verne to spationaut Doctor on surface of Axos,
DOCTOR: respond please.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 105
DOCTOR WHO: SCENE 62: EXT. SPACE — SURFACE OF AXOS
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Radio’s gone dead. That’s odd.
DAVID: (SUIT MIC) I can hear you fine.
EVELYN: (SUIT MIC) Me too. Maybe the problem’s at their end?
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) There they are. They’re still coming towards us. Try waving. “Hello!”
JOANNE: (SUIT MIC) Look, their cargo bay’s open. What are they doing?
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) I rather think they intend to get us inside.
DAVID: (SUIT MIC) Yeah, they’re extending the cargo arm now. Here it comes.
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Mister Brock, can you see anything to attach yourself onto?
DAVID: (SUIT MIC) Looks like foot restraints on the end there. I’ve used one before.
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Right. We should probably carefully unclip ourselves, grab onto it and have a word with them once we’re inside their ship. I’m sure they’re very pleasant people, willing to listen to reasoned argument.
JOANNE: (SUIT MIC) Doctor, our mission here is a legitimate claim on Axon resources.
DAVID: (SUIT MIC) Alright, Jo.
JOANNE: (SUIT MIC) What?
DOCTOR WHO: THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 106
DAVID: (SUIT MIC) Just leave it.
JOANNE: (SUIT MIC) They can’t stop us. This is free enterprise, it’s a human right.
DAVID: (SUIT MIC) But what if they don’t see it that way? What do we do then? Fight?
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) David’s right. Your best bet right now is to co- operate. Now, whatever happens, keep yourselves hooked onto the line until we’re ready. We don’t want anyone floating off. Ready, Evelyn?
EVELYN: (SUIT MIC) Oh dear.
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Oh dear what?
EVELYN: (SUIT MIC) I unhooked myself when you said we were going over. Just then. I thought it was an instruction.
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Well — hook yourself back onto Axos again, quickly.
EVELYN: (SUIT MIC) Trouble is... (EFFORT) .. I can’t quite reach it.
DAVID: (SUIT MIC) Here let me.
EVELYN: (SUIT MIC) It’s silly, it’s only a couple of inches away. Maybe if turn this way -
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) No! Whatever you do, stay perfectly still!
JOANNE: (SUIT MIC) Evelyn, stop! Stop, please.
EVELYN: (SUIT MIC) But I’m only a couple of inches away from the line, (EFFORT) I’m sure I can... (BEAT) Oh. It’s more like six inches now.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 107
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Evelyn, don’t move. Whatever happens, don’t move a muscle. Remember, Newton’s third law!
EVELYN: (SUIT MIC) But it’s no more than a foot away. Surely you can just jump and get me?
DAVID: (SUIT MIC) Hold the line, Jo. I’m going to push off and grab her. Ready? Here we go.
EVELYN: (SUIT MIC) Oh! Missed you!
JOANNE: (SUIT MIC) It’s too late. We’ve lost her.
EVELYN: (SUIT MIC) What are you talking about, I’m still here. Not two feet away from you.
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Here. I’m unhooking too. Daisy chain. Jo, stay attached to Axos. You hold David, I’1l hold him. You ready?
JOANNE: (SUIT MIC) Doctor, she’s too far out. The safety line is already stretched as far as it’1ll go. You’1l never reach her.
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Well of course I will.
JOANNE: (SUIT MIC) What are you doing?
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Unhooking myself from the safety line and... detaching my oxygen supply. I can use it to propel myself. Push equals shove!
DAVID: (SUIT MIC) And then what? You’1ll both go floating off together.
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) In which case, get the Jules Verne over there to pick us up.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 108
JOANNE: (SUIT MIC) It’s not ‘over there’ any more.
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) What-? Well, where’s it gone?
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Doesn’t matter now. I have to save Evelyn!
JOANNE: (SUIT MIC) Even if you reach her, Doctor, it’d be suicide.
JOANNE: By the time the Jules Verne comes round again, you’1ll already be miles away, in a new orbit. You’1l qualify as a couple of extra moons.
EVELYN: (SUIT MIC) I can hear, you know!
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Never mind them, Evelyn. Concentrate on me. Concentrate on my voice.
DOCTOR: RANGE.
EVELYN: (SUIT MIC) How far away from you all am I now? Twenty feet? Thirty? I can’t seem to judge the distance any more.
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Evelyn. Please, stay very still, any additional motion might cause you to accelerate. I’1l be with you as soon as I can.
DAVID: (SUIT MIC) Doctor. You have to let her go.
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Don’t be ridiculous.
EVELYN: (SUIT MIC) They’re right, Doctor. It’s too late for me now. You look after yourselves.
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Evelyn, I’1l find you, do you hear me? I’1l1 find you, and I’1l bring you back.
DOCTOR WHO: THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 109
EVELYN: (SUIT MIC) Don’t worry, Doctor. It’s not your fault. Silly,
EVELYN: idiotic woman, messing around in space like Barbarella. At my age. Goodbye, Doctor. My dear, dear [Doctor —]
DOCTOR: (SUIT MIC) Evelyn. Evelyn!!!
DOCTOR: END OF PART THREE
DOCTOR WHO: THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 110

elements.text: PART FOUR
(SUIT MIC) Evelyn, I’ll find you, do you hear me? I’1ll find you, and I’1l bring you back.
(SUIT MIC) Don’t worry, Doctor. It’s not your fault. Silly, idiotic woman, messing around in space like Barbarella. At my age. Goodbye, Doctor. My dear, dear [Doctor —]
FX: HER SUIT MIC CUTS OUT AS SHE GOES OUT OF RANGE. STATIC.
(SUIT MIC) Evelyn. Evelyn!!!
SCENE 63: EVELYN’S POV — INSIDE SPACESUIT
FX: EVELYN DRIFTING IN SPACE.
Look. I can see The British Isles. “England. With all thy faults I love thee still.” I remember learning that at school. Funny what pops into one’s head sometimes.
(IN HER OWN RADIO) [“With] all thy faults, I love thee still.”
Hello, is there an echo in here-?
(IN HER OWN RADIO) Funny what pops into one’s head [sometimes. ]
This is most peculiar!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 111
SCENE 64: EXT. SPACE — SURFACE OF AXOS
(SUIT MIC) She’s gone. I can’t see her. Oh, Evelyn.
(SUIT MIC) I’m sorry, Doctor.
(SUIT MIC) I’ll get her back. She has enough oxygen to last for a while yet.
FX: HUM OF THE MICROWAVE RECEIVER FROM OFF.
(SUIT MIC) Look! On the Windermere!
(SUIT MIC) The microwave transmitter! Someone’s activated the microwave transmitter!
(SUIT MIC) It’s not transmitting. It’s receiving! Axos is using the beam as a weapon.
(SUIT MIC) Yes, and it’s targeted at the Jules Verne!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 112
SCENE 65: EVELYN’S POV — INSIDE SPACESUIT
FX: MESSAGES FROM THE PAST AND FUTURE FUZZING IN AND OUT INSIDE
EVELYN’S HELMET.
TIME LeFEVRE: (RADIO) This is shuttle Jules Verne! We are under attack!
What? Oh, the other spaceship. What’s Axos doing to it?
TIME LeFEVRE:
(RADIO) Fuel cells empty, emergency back-up on ten per-cent. Hydraulics not responding, no telemetry readout. We are instigating emergency evacuation! (SCREAMS) M’aider! M’aider! Arret!
All that energy pouring out. Pretty lights, like the aurora borealis. Those poor people [inside.] — (BLINKS) — Well, hold
on a moment, where’s it gone-? (BEAT) I must be seeing things. Oh, Doctor, it’s getting cold. So cold...
(RADIO) This is the spaceship Windermere. Our mission is a success. Axos is safe. Repeat, Axos is made safe.
No, don’t go. Can you hear me?
LeFEVRE: (RADIO) This is shuttle Jules Verne! We are under [attack! ]
(IN HER OWN RADIO) Funny what pops into one’s head [sometimes. ]

I know what this is! It’s the time loop! I must have floated to the edge of the time loop. I’m hearing echoes from the past and the future. Which means... Oh, I don’t know what it means. I need the Doctor.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 113
SCENE 66: INT. AXOS — GILLS
FX: WE’RE ON THE INSIDE OF AXOS’ GILLS. HEAVY MEAT ‘CURTAINS’
SHIFTING IN AND OUT AS AXOS ‘BREATHES’.
FX: SIMULTANEOUSLY, HEAVY BREATHING EFFORT FROM DOCTOR, JO AND
AS THE CLAMBER THROUGH.
Nearly there, Jo. Come on.
Pull, will you!
I am pulling —
FX: WITH A POPPING SOUND, JO AND DAVID TUMBLE THROUGH THE
GILLS. LANDING HEAVILY.
Well, where are we now?
On the inside of Axos’s gills.
Gills?
It’s a living organism, it has to breathe. In space, however — (FX: RAISES HELMET VISOR) (DEEP BREATH) .. the gills give Axos
its very own airlock. Oh, that’s better.
(FX: RAISES HELMET VISOR) It’s safe. We can breathe! That’s incredible!
You too, Jo. Jo-?
Sorry. (FX: RAISES VISOR) Doctor, the Jules Verne. What happened to the Jules Verne-?
Hmm? Oh. Absorbed by Axos, I’m afraid.
What, you didn’t see-?
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 114
See what?
It disappeared. I saw it. It was under attack, and then it — well, it just winked out of existence.
It disappeared before, when the arm was coming out.
Time phenomena. Ghosts from the past, and the future. Only to be expected on the edge of a time loop.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 115
SCENE 67: EVELYN’S POV — INSIDE SPACESUIT
FX: MESSAGES FROM THE PAST AND FUTURE FUZZING IN AND OUT INSIDE
EVELYN’S HELMET.
(RADIO) This is the spaceship Windermere. Our mission is a success. Axos is safe. Repeat, Axos is made safe.
I wish there was some way of turning this thing off, it’s getting very repetitive.
LeFEVRE:
(RADIO — SUDDENLY VERY CLEAR AND QUITE LOUD) This is the Eurozone shuttle Jules Verne to unidentified spationaut, respond please.
What? Oh my goodness. I can see you! Where did you spring from?
LeFEVRE: (RADIO) I think we ask you this, no?
You don’t understand. I saw your ship destroyed not ten minutes ago.
LeFEVRE : (RADIO) We have only just passed through the time threshold. I repeat, who are you?
I’m Dr Evelyn Smythe. And I’m jolly glad to see you!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 116
SCENE 68: INT. AXOS — PASSAGEWAY
FX: RUMBLE THROUGH SHIP.
(WALKING) What was that?
(WALKING) We’re moving. Axos must be using up its energy reserves to try to escape from the time barrier.
(WALKING) The Windermere is still attached to the hull of Axos.

(WALKING) In which case, it’s coming with us. (STOPPING) The question is — how does Axos intend to cross the time threshold? You used an alien displacement device, but it’s not compastible with Axos’s biology.
Perhaps it’s found another way out.
Impossible. I mean, Axos is clever, but a time loop is a Time Lord weapon. It’d need help...
Your friend, Thomas Brewster. Could he have helped them?
(SNORTS) I doubt it. Traversing a time threshold is way beyond his abilities.
Someone else, then. Someone like yourself?
Another Time Lord? I wouldn’t have thought so. (A THOUGHT) Unless...
What?

Unless they replicated me! That’s it, of course! Axos captured me, earlier. It must have realised I was worth far more to it than mere nutrition, and made a copy of me. The drain on its resources would have been huge.
Huge? Why?
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 117
No offence, but my mind and physiology are so far beyond a human’s, it’s like comparing a parsley pig to the Hanging Gardens of Babylon.
You’re too modest.
Somewhere on this vessel is an Axon construct, with my memories, my knowledge, my abilities. And if gains possession of the TARDIS — Axos could infect the time stream itself!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 118
SCENE 69: INT. AXOS — EYE CHAMBER
There are intruders in Axos.
How can you tell?
I am Axos. I surround them.
It is the Doctor. I can sense his mind. intelligence and cunning.
It burns with
We must have the Doctor’s machine. His TARDIS.
It has evolved since we last encountered it. Last time, it was a shivering thing, cowering from the Time Lords’ cruelty. Now
it is strong, regenerated.
And you could fly it? Go anywhere you wanted?
Yes. Are we not the Doctor now?
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 119
SCENE 70: INT. FLIGHT DECK OF SPACESHIP JULES VERNE
FX: DOOR SLIDES OPEN.
(SUIT MIC) Er, hello-?
Dr Smythe. Please, come in. The flight deck is pressurised. You may lift your visor?

(SUIT MIC) Oh! Of course. (LIFTING VISOR — MIC OFF) Sorry, I’m a little discombobulated, after my lift on your cargo arm. I say, what a tidy ship. It’s like what submarines would look like if they were designed by Scandinavians. Clean lines. Good storage.
LeFEVRE: (BEMUSED) I thank you. Commandant Philippe LeFevre, spationaut.
Orlogskaptein Svenni Nilson, romfarer. At your service, Ms Smythe.
Enchanté. I don’t suppose you have a cup of tea?
LeFEVRE: This is a spaceship.
Oh well, one lives in hope.
We do have some brandy, however.
Isn’t alcohol forbidden up here?
LeFEVRE: Oui.
Nevertheless, it’s a little early in the morning for me.
Tell us, Dr Smythe. Your friend, the Doctor. He is the Doctor, is he not?
(WARY) He might be.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB)
LeFEVRE: TARDIS, UNIT, the Master — that Doctor?
You seem remarkably well-informed, Monsieur LeFevre.
LeFEVRE : We have been in contact with Geneva. We know the history Axos. It was not hard to work out.
I must say — this makes a change from having to convince that I’m not a spy, or a saboteur!
LeFEVRE:
Non. You are an ordinary woman with no special training, qualification for space warfare - and who exists outside international law.
Page 120
of
people
no of
Whereas we represent untold trillions of Euromarks of Eurozone investment and training, backed up by the combined armed forces
of the governments of twenty-five countries.
LeFEVRE : And as such we are entirely at your disposal, Madame.
Where would you like us to start?
I say.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 121
SCENE 71: INT. AXOS — EYE CHAMBER
FX: AXOS ALARUMS.
Alert. Alert. Spaceship Jules Verne now in range of microwave receiver.
Then we must feed. Thomas Brewster, you will communicate with this vessel.
Look, I don’t want no-one hurt —
If Axos cannot feed on the Jules Verne —
. Axos shall feed on you.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 122
SCENE 72: INT. FLIGHT DECK OF SPACESHIP JULES VERNE
(RADIO) Axos calling spaceship Jules Verne. Over.
What was that-?
LeFEVRE:
Quiet, please. (RADIO) This is Eurozone Space Agency shuttle Jules Verne, operating under the authority of the Eurozone Space agency. Please state your identity. Over.
(RADIO) This is astronaut Thomas Brewster calling. I’m on Axos. We thought it was alive, but it’s not. Fact is, it’s as dead as a doornail. We’re stuck here.
LeFEVRE: What is the status of your ship?
(RADIO) Yeah, the ship. The — um — the engine’s blown a gasket.
LeFEVRE: You’re sure Axos is dormant? Repeat, is Axos in a dormant state?
(RADIO) Dead as a five day floater in the Thames.
LeFEVRE : Repeat that please?
(RADIO) It’s dead, yes. You can dock at the front. See the funnel-shaped area? Head for that, then drift in slow as you can.
Phillipe, give me the comms. (INTO RADIO) Would that be directly in range of the Windermere’s microwave receiver, astronaut Brewster?
(RADIO) I don’t... Evelyn? Evelyn, is that you?
And if you thinking of luring us to our doom, you’ve got another think coming! You should be ashamed of yourself, Thomas Brewster.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 123
(OFF) (RADIO) Cease transmission! —
FX: RADIO CUTS TO STATIC.
Well. That told him.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 124
SCENE 73: INT. AXOS — EYE CHAMBER
You have failed us, Thomas Brewster!
You will be absorbed into Axos!
No, no — please! I weren’t to know old Mother Hubbard was aboard. It weren’t my fault! (DESPERATE) The TARDIS. The Doctor’s TARDIS. What if I could get you inside? What would that be worth to you?
That would be worth the price of the universe.
Hang about — you should have the key. You copied the Doctor, you’ll have copied the key!
The key was — complicated. It is no ordinary key.
Well then, best I get you the real one.
You will bring us the key.
And in return, you’1ll give up on your plan to take over the Earth?
With all of time and space to feast on, we can afford to leave your puny planet alone.
No, no, no. I don’t want you to leave it alone. Not exactly. I want you to give it to me.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 125
SCENE 74: INT. AXOS — PASSAGEWAY
FX: SNAPPING OF TENDRILS.
(WALKING) There’s tendrils everywhere-!
(WALKING) Then I suggest you avoid them, Ms Slade. Don’t flap about, we don’t want Axos any more awake than it already is.
I don’t understand. Where’s it got all this energy from? The Windermere?

The microwave device you intended to use to beam energy to earth. It’s been reversed. I can only assume, Axos is sucking energy directly from the national power grid. Even as we speak, the lights are probably going out all across the United Kingdom.
How is that possible?
It’s quite simple. I told them how to do it.
What?
Well, not me. I mean my duplicate. My doppelganger.
(OFF) You’re wrong, Doctor.
Thomas Brewster. Fancy meeting you here.
Oh, so you’re glad to see me, are you? You’re wrong, Doctor — about the microwave doo-dah. Axos got its power from draining Devesham alone.
Devesham? It drained Devesham?
Of course. Transmitting energy back through the displacement device on the Windermere, connected to Devesham! Well, this is good news!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 126
Good news?!? All our friends, all our colleagues — you’re saying they’re dead!
Campbell Irons, too.

So much for his scheme. Jo, Mr Brock — I don’t mean to sound heartless. The point is, Axos could only drain Devesham because Axos was linked directly to Devesham, through the displacement field. But the time threshold remains in place. Axos can’t target anywhere else on the Earth, not unless that barrier is broken.
You mean, it’s not too late to save the world?
Old mum Smythe, she’s safe too. The Jules Verne picked her up.
The Jules Verne? But we saw it destroyed. Sucked dry!
Naah. I spoke to her. Tipped her the wink. Changed the future, I guess.
Thank goodness. Thank you, Thomas.
Yeah, geddoff!
Changed the future? How is that possible-?
Within the confines of the time loop, it’s very possible!
The transmission we heard on the Windermere, Jo. Your transmission. Saying the mission had succeeded, and Axos was safe —
It wasn’t real. Like the destruction of the Jules Verne. None of it was real!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 127
A four-dimensional mirage, I’m afraid. The ghost of a possible reality? Maybe, maybe not. Time is in flux, it’s hard to say.
Then we can change things. David, we can change things!
Roger that.
Ms Slade? Are you going somewhere?
Remember Campbell’s back-up plan? The nuclear reactor, on the Windermere?
Jo. It’s not come to that. Not yet.
But it might do. Good luck, Doctor.
I was there, Joanne, when the British space programme was in its infancy. Those who worked on it were fearless, brave pioneers. I’m glad to see that flame still burning.
Thank you, Doctor. And good luck. Come on, David.
FX: JOANNE AND DAVID RUN.
(CALLING AFTER) Send a message to Evelyn! Tell them to get out of the time loop, fast as they can! (BEAT) Come on, Thomas. We need to get back to the TARDIS.
You won’t be doing nothing without the key, Doctor.
Well, where did you get that [from-?] (CROSS) Did you just pick my pocket?
Once a thief, always a thief — ain’t that right?
You give that back this instant!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 128
Uh, uh, uh! Thing is, Doctor — I don’t trust you. I heard what you said to Evelyn, about leaving me to die.
But — you can’t have! What I mean is, I didn’t-!
Which is why, well, I’ve decided to live up to your expectations. You’re prepared to let me die to save yourself, why should I be any different?
Thomas, whatever you may have heard, I promise you, it was never my intention —
Don’t tell me, you were just doing your best. Well, I’m doing my best. Looking out for number one. Which is why I’ve made me a deal.
A deal? Who with?
(STEPPING IN FROM OFF) A deal... with me.
Well, well, well. What have we here? It’s a good attempt, I give you that. Not sure you’ve quite captured my nose, though.
Extrude the Doctor’s vessel.
FX: SLOOPING EFFECT AS THE TARDIS EMERGES FROM THE WALL.
Right then. Here’s his TARDIS. And here’s the key, like I
promised.
You have done well, Thomas Brewster.
(ALL AROUND) Now, Doctor. Now you will give us our freedom!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 129
SCENE 75: INT. BRIDGE OF SPACESHIP JULES VERNE
LeFEVRE: Svenni, can you take us in any closer?
Sorry Philippe. Either we will be caught by the microwave energy or the time distortion may eject us from the barrier altogether.
LeFEVRE : What about manual delivery?
Manual what? What are you talking about?
LeFEVRE: We have a bomb. We could use it.
A bomb?! ?
LeFEVRE: Only as a final option.
(RADIO) Our mission is a success. Axos is safe. Repeat, Axos is made safe.
Time distortion again.
I’m still not getting this, though. How is their mission a success? We abandoned the Windermere and were making along the outside to try and get to the Doctor’s, er —
His TARDIS, yes. Like we say, we know all about the Doctor.
Right. But even if they managed to get onboard, how does that qualify as a success? Or is this some sort of possible future? A potential future that might be, but not necessarily?
LeFEVRE: So we sit and wait, to see what happens. Then, if Axos is not made safe after all, we step in.
With your bomb.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 130
LeFEVRE : As I said — it is the final option.
(RADIO) This is spaceship Windermere, calling spaceship Jules Verne! Come in, please-!
Jules Verne, [receiving-]
Spare us the jargon. Turn tail and cross the time threshold. Repeat, cross the time threshold!
On whose authority-?
The Doctor’s! Do it! Do it now!
Well, you heard the man, Phillipe!
LeFEVRE: Burn, Svenni! Burn!!!
FX: ENGINES BURN.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 131
SCENE 76: INT. FLIGHT DECK OF SPACESHIP WINDERMERE
FX: JOANNE RUSHING IN, DOOR RESEALING BEHIND.
All clear? Jo?
Yeah. Amazing what a chainsaw can do to an Axonoid. (FX:
UP, STRAPPING IN) Where’s the Jules Verne?
FX: RADAR BLIPS.
Approaching the time threshold in five, four, three, two, one... They’ve gone.
Then Evelyn Smythe is safe, at least. Status of Windermere.
FX: LEVERS, SWITCHES.
We’re still held tight by Axos. If I go for full thrust, it’1l blow the ship apart before Axos lets go.
And set off Campbell’s booby-trap, on the reactor?
Yes.
(RADIO) This is the spaceship Windermere. Our mission is a success. Axos is safe. Repeat, Axos is made safe.
That message again. Bouncing around the time loop.
It’s not a mirage, David. Listen. ‘Axos is made safe’. Meaning we stop the threat. That’s our mission. That’s our ‘success’.
I have a family.
Then all the more reason.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 132
SCENE 77: INT. TARDIS CONTROL ROOM
FX: NORMAL ATMOS. DOCTOR COMPLETES BUTTON-PRESSING SEQUENCE.
There. That’s the maths done. Dematerialise the TARDIS, and Axos will follow it out of the loop.
I know you, Doctor. As well as you know yourself. You will have tricked us.
In that case, my Axon doppelganger, you’re welcome to check the program. Go ahead, be my guest.
FX: BUTTONS.
There is... no trick.
See?
(SLIGHTLY OFF) Course there is.
Thomas Brewster? What do you mean?
Prestidigitation, old chum. You’re looking at one hand, but the trick’s being done with the other.
(GRABBING BREWSTER BY THROAT) What... do you mean?
Alright, alright! (RELEASED) What I mean is, the Windermere’s about to blow up. Axos’1ll stay stuck in the loop, feeding over and over on the explosion.
Have you no decency, Thomas Brewster-?
Just looking out for meself, Doctor. I’d say sorry, but I can’t say I am, much.
Then — I must dematerialise this vessel!
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 133
No!!!
FX: TARDIS DEMATERIALISING.
THE FEAST OF AXOS by Mike Maddox (005 — AB) Page 134
SCENE 78: INT. FLIGHT DECK OF SPACESHIP WINDERMERE

(INTO COMMS) This is the spaceship Windermere. Our mission is a success. Axos is safe. Repeat, Axos is made safe. We brought this on ourselves, but through our actions we hope we have redeemed the good name of the British Space Programme, and those who went before us. If anyone receives this message, please tell our families that our last thoughts... Our last thoughts were of them. And that we ask them to forgive us.
Ready to go for full thrust.
Ready.
Then here goes nothing. Three, two, one —
